comments.body:
dont reassign options.limit_to_modules, just created a new limit_to_modules var

``` python
if options.limit_to_modules is not None:
    limit_to_modules = [s.lower() for s in options.limit_to_modules.split(",")]

mod_info, categories, aliases = list_modules(options.module_dir, limit_to_modules=limit_to_modules)

```

I wouldn't block on this but stylewise, I do agree with alikins that it's better to do all modifications of things in options inside of the argument parsing functions and then set other variables if the code is outside of it.   (In my own code I tend to have a parse_options function that would combine generate_parser, validate_options, and also do transformations on the arguments like this.  That function would return the options data structure at the end and then I'd try to treat it as immutable thereafter).

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +455,459 @@    # Convert passed-in limit_to_modules to None or list of modules.
    if options.limit_to_modules is not None:
        options.limit_to_modules = [s.lower() for s in options.limit_to_modules.split(",")]

    mod_info, categories, aliases = list_modules(options.module_dir, limit_to_modules=options.limit_to_modules)

comments.body: should we use 'plugins' instead in view of extending the coverage?

comments.body:
@dagwieers `str` is also `Sequence`. So it's either docstring or the check is misleading.
You might want to add `and not isinstance(value, str)`

Yup, I know: https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/37517/files#diff-bc6bf5732a9c00dcb3cb182f4ce3b7c8R100

But that's no longer my problem now, is it :-)
This will work for what we currently have, though we will not be able to link to a non-module plugin using using the`  M(..)` option. I think that's OK though.
Yeah, for the future, we'll have to have macros for each of the plugin types.  This simple regex can't handle that.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +92,96 @@        t = _ITALIC.sub(r"*\1*", text)
        t = _BOLD.sub(r"**\1**", t)
        t = _MODULE.sub(r":ref:`\1 <\1_module>`", t)
        t = _LINK.sub(r"`\1 <\2>`_", t)
        t = _URL.sub(r"\1", t)

comments.body: So while it's been said that this would only be python-centric code, as I suspected it is now trickling into the Jinja filter. Sequence, list, strings, the mess is even messier now :-/ Both in Ansible python and Jinja.
It's just a helper function. So everyone reinventing it would not have to do this again.
You probably don't need `{}` fallback anymore.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +289,293 @@        if 'options' in doc and doc['options'] is None:
            display.error("*** ERROR: DOCUMENTATION.options must be a dictionary/hash when used. ***")
            pos = getattr(doc, "ansible_pos", None)
            if pos is not None:
                display.error("Module position: %s, %d, %d" % doc.ansible_pos)

comments.body: If we start expanding type names, we should have a sanity checks which prevents people from using the long names in `type:` of their documentation. (IMO)
That's already in place, you can't just invent new types.
I know, I have another PR #50010 that cleans up the Return Values bits (more consistency).
